text: Cats cannot taste sweet things due to a defect in the gene that codes for part of the mammalian sweet taste receptor - this defect occurs in domestic cats, cheetahs, and tigers alike.
About half of all cats don't respond to catnip at all - sensitivity to Nepeta cataria is inherited, with cats having one sensitive parent having a 50% chance of developing the sensitivity.
Penguin coloring is camouflage - from above, their black back blends into ocean depths, while from below, their white belly is hidden against the bright surface.
Cats have a gene called Taqpep that determines whether they have stripes, spots, or blotched patterns - blotched cats have mutations on both copies of the gene.
For some penguin species, pudgy males with enough fat to survive weeks without eating are most desirable mates - males incubate eggs while females hunt for weeks.

Great white shark teeth are continuously replaced like a conveyor belt, roughly every few weeks - the design changes to match their diet as they grow from fish-eating juveniles to marine-mammal-hunting adults.
Scientists have identified specific epigenetic switches that can slow the production of fat cells.

Unlike virtually all other birds, the New Caledonian crow has a bill that doesn't curve downward - scientists believe it evolved this way to help grasp tools more easily and see what the tool is doing.
Goats' horizontal rectangular pupils give them a sharp panoramic view that lets them see nearly all around themselves - this helps them detect predators from various directions.
Pupil shape reveals an animal's role in the food chain - predators that ambush prey tend to have vertical slit pupils, while herbivores that are prey usually have horizontal pupils.
Vertical slit pupils help small ambush predators like cats and snakes judge distance for pouncing, while bigger cats and wolves have round pupils because they need to chase down prey.
The genetic lines of Poecilia koperi and P. wandae blur in areas where they meet, likely due to occasional hybridization.
Humans share 60% of their DNA with bananas and 98.8% with chimpanzees.
Your DNA is bombarded by about 10,000 molecular lesions per cell per day, but repair mechanisms fix most of them before they cause problems.
Your body has enough DNA to stretch from the Sun to Pluto and back — about 17 times.
Goosebumps evolved to make our ancestors' hair stand up and appear larger to predators — now they're vestigial.
Whales evolved from land mammals — they still have tiny leg bones inside their bodies.
Chickens are the closest living relatives to T. rex.
Sharks have been around longer than trees.
Humans share 50% of their DNA with bananas.
Some people are born without fingerprints due to a rare genetic condition called adermatoglyphia.
Goosebumps are a vestigial response — our ancestors' hair would fluff up to appear larger or for insulation.
Wisdom teeth are becoming less common — about 35% of people now never develop them.
Humans share 70% of their DNA with slugs.
Sharks have been around longer than trees — 400 million vs 350 million years.
Your DNA could stretch from the Sun to Pluto and back 17 times.
Humans and bananas share 60% of their DNA.
Humans and chimps share 98.8% of their DNA, but humans and bananas share about 60%.
The human genome contains about 8% viral DNA — remnants of ancient infections that became part of us.
Your DNA is bombarded by about 10,000 damaging events per cell per day, but repair mechanisms fix most of them.
Identical twins don't have identical fingerprints because fingerprints are influenced by random developmental factors.
The average person carries 1-2 lethal genetic mutations that would be fatal if inherited from both parents.
Whales evolved from land mammals — they still have tiny vestigial leg bones inside their bodies.
Snakes have vestigial hips and some species have tiny remnant legs, showing their lizard ancestry.
The human tailbone is a vestigial tail — some babies are occasionally born with small tails.
Chickens are the closest living relatives of T. rex, and birds are technically dinosaurs.
Evolution has independently created eyes over 40 times in different lineages.
The recurrent laryngeal nerve takes a 15-foot detour in giraffes — an evolutionary leftover from fish ancestors.
Red hair is caused by a variant of the MC1R gene and is the rarest natural hair color at 1-2% of the population.
Lactose tolerance in adults is a mutation that appeared only 10,000 years ago with dairy farming.
Blue eyes appeared as a mutation 6,000-10,000 years ago — every blue-eyed person shares a common ancestor.
Wisdom teeth are becoming obsolete — about 35% of people never develop them.
The appendix isn't vestigial — it's a refuge for beneficial gut bacteria to repopulate after illness.
Goosebumps are vestigial — they fluffed up our ancestors' fur for warmth or to appear larger.
Humans are 99.9% genetically identical to each other, yet that 0.1% difference creates all human diversity.
Neanderthal DNA makes up 1-4% of modern non-African human genomes.
CRISPR was discovered as a bacterial immune system that cuts up invading viral DNA.
Epigenetics shows that experiences can affect gene expression and be passed to future generations.
Mitochondrial DNA is inherited only from mothers, allowing us to trace maternal lineages back 200,000 years.
Sharks have been around for over 400 million years — predating trees and dinosaurs.
Horseshoe crabs have remained virtually unchanged for 450 million years.
Woolly mammoth DNA has been extracted and scientists are attempting to resurrect the species.
Bacteria can exchange genes horizontally, not just through reproduction — this is how antibiotic resistance spreads.
The Y chromosome is slowly shrinking and may disappear in about 4.6 million years.
Humans have lost the ability to produce vitamin C due to a mutation 61 million years ago.
Some humans can see a fourth primary color due to a mutation that creates tetrachromacy.
The placenta evolved from an ancient viral infection that became beneficial.
Tibetans have a gene from Denisovans that helps them survive at high altitudes.
Polar bears evolved from brown bears only about 400,000 years ago — very recently in evolutionary terms.
Dogs were the first domesticated animal, diverging from wolves about 15,000-40,000 years ago.
Antibiotic-resistant superbugs are an example of evolution happening in real-time.
The common ancestor of all life on Earth is called LUCA — Last Universal Common Ancestor.
Only 1.5% of human DNA codes for proteins — the rest was once called 'junk DNA' but has important regulatory functions.
Humans have fewer genes than a grape — about 20,000 compared to the grape's 30,000.
Humans are more closely related to fungi than to plants.
The first flowers appeared about 140 million years ago, relatively recently in Earth's history.
Octopus DNA is so different from other animals that some scientists joked they might be alien.
The Cambrian Explosion produced most major animal body plans in just 20 million years.
Feathers evolved before flight — dinosaurs used them for insulation and display.
Cave fish lose their eyes over generations because maintaining unused organs wastes energy.
A 2015 study found that the average person has about 400 private genetic variants that are unique to them.
Epigenetics studies gene expression changes without DNA changes.
DNA methylation can silence genes.
Histone modifications affect gene expression.
Imprinting means some genes are only expressed from one parent.
X-inactivation silences one X chromosome in females.
Epigenetic changes can be inherited.
Twins can have different epigenomes.
Environmental factors can cause epigenetic changes.
Stress can alter gene expression epigenetically.
Diet affects epigenetic markers.
Epigenetic clocks can estimate biological age.
Horvath's clock uses DNA methylation patterns.
Biological age can differ from chronological age.
Epigenetic age acceleration predicts mortality.
Lifestyle factors affect epigenetic age.
Exercise can reverse some epigenetic aging.
Caloric restriction slows epigenetic aging.
Smoking accelerates epigenetic aging.
Alcohol affects DNA methylation patterns.
Meditation may slow epigenetic aging.
Sleep deprivation alters gene expression.
Pollution can cause epigenetic changes.
Endocrine disruptors affect epigenetics.
Bisphenol A can alter gene expression.
Transgenerational epigenetic inheritance is controversial.
Famine effects may be inherited epigenetically.
The Dutch Hunger Winter study showed transgenerational effects.
Trauma may cause inheritable epigenetic changes.
Holocaust survivor descendants show epigenetic changes.
Paternal diet can affect offspring epigenetics.
Grandparental experiences may affect grandchildren.
Sperm carry epigenetic information.
Paternal obesity affects offspring metabolism.
Cocaine use alters sperm epigenetics.
Paternal stress affects offspring behavior.
Maternal care affects offspring epigenetics.
Rat pup licking affects stress response genes.
Early life stress has lasting epigenetic effects.
Abuse alters glucocorticoid receptor methylation.
Depression is linked to epigenetic changes.
Antidepressants may work through epigenetics.
Schizophrenia involves epigenetic changes.
Autism is linked to epigenetic factors.
Addiction causes lasting epigenetic changes.
Drug tolerance involves epigenetic mechanisms.
Reward pathways are epigenetically modified by drugs.
Relapse is linked to epigenetic memory.
Goosebumps are a vestigial response from hairy ancestors.
Wisdom teeth are becoming less common in humans.
The appendix may be a vestigial organ.
The coccyx is a remnant of a tail.
Humans once had a third eyelid.
Arrector pili muscles cause goosebumps.
The palmaris longus muscle is absent in 14% of people.
Darwin's tubercle is a vestigial ear feature.
The plantaris muscle is vestigial in humans.
The pyramidalis muscle is absent in 20% of people.
Male nipples are vestigial structures.
Hiccups may be a remnant from amphibian ancestors.
The pharyngeal arches develop into neck structures.
Human embryos temporarily have tails.
Lanugo is fetal hair humans once kept.
The vomeronasal organ is vestigial in humans.
Humans have genes for making vitamin C but they're broken.
Olfactory receptor genes are mostly non-functional in humans.
Humans have lost the ability to make 1 of 20 amino acids.
Humans cannot biosynthesize vitamin B12.
GULO gene is broken in humans, causing need for vitamin C.
Humans have 3 billion base pairs in their genome.
Only 1.5% of human DNA codes for proteins.
Humans have about 20,000 protein-coding genes.
Transposons make up 45% of the human genome.
Mitochondrial DNA is inherited only from mothers.
Y chromosome DNA is inherited only from fathers.
Humans and chimpanzees share 98.8% of DNA.
Humans and mice share 85% of protein-coding genes.
Humans and fruit flies share 60% of genes.
Humans have 23 pairs of chromosomes.
Chromosome 1 is the largest human chromosome.
Chromosome 21 is the smallest autosome.
The Y chromosome is one of the smallest.
Telomeres shorten with each cell division.
Telomerase can extend telomeres.
Cancer cells have abnormal telomerase activity.
CRISPR can edit genes with high precision.
Cas9 is the enzyme that cuts DNA in CRISPR.
Guide RNA directs CRISPR to the target gene.
PCR amplifies DNA exponentially.
DNA sequencing has become 100 million times cheaper.
The Human Genome Project took 13 years.
Sanger sequencing reads one DNA strand at a time.
Next-gen sequencing reads millions of strands at once.
Oxford Nanopore can sequence DNA in real-time.
23andMe uses DNA microarrays.
SNPs are single nucleotide changes.
Indels are insertions or deletions in DNA.
Copy number variants affect large DNA segments.
Octopuses can edit their own RNA on the fly.
Humans share 60% of DNA with bananas.
Grass appeared only about 55 million years ago — it's a relatively recent plant.
Avocados evolved to be eaten by giant ground sloths — now extinct, so humans have taken over seed dispersal.
Fungi were the first organisms to colonize land, paving the way for plants.
Human DNA is 50% identical to banana DNA.
Humans share 60% of their DNA with bananas.
A single human cell contains about 6 feet of DNA.
The human genome contains about 3 billion base pairs of DNA.
